security: This document reveals CIA's responses to inquiries about the JFK assassination and actions related to critics of the Warren Report, including the existence of guidance (Book Dispatch 5847) to CIA stations for countering criticism. Disclosing these responses and actions could be interpreted as an admission of CIA involvement in shaping public perception of the Warren Commission's findings. Quoting directly: 'Tab 11 contains a copy of Book Dispatch 5847 which transmitted guidance to certain CIA stations and bases concerning the countering of criticism of the Warren Report.' and 'CIA has continued to be alert for new information abroad concerning this matter, and the Oswald file has grown over the years.'
summary: A 1975 CIA memorandum provides answers to questions raised by Paul Hoch, a critic of the Warren Commission, regarding the agency's involvement in the JFK assassination, including inquiries about Lee Harvey Oswald, connections to individuals and organizations, and actions taken in response to the assassination.
summary_one_paragraph: In April 1975, E.H. Knoche of the CIA sent a memorandum to Robert B. Olsen, addressing questions posed by Paul Hoch concerning the CIA's role in the JFK assassination and related matters. The memorandum details CIA's responses to Hoch's inquiries about potential CIA connections to Lee Harvey Oswald, the agency's knowledge of Oswald's activities in Mexico City, relationships with individuals like Guy Banister and David Ferrie, investigations into critics of the Warren Report, and actions taken following the assassination. It clarifies that Oswald was never a CIA informant, addresses the agency's handling of the Zapruder film, and explains the purpose of a CIA-State study on defectors, providing attachments and references to relevant documents and testimonies.
title: CIA Comments on Questions Raised by Mr. Paul Hoch
